title: Matrices: Definitions, Examples, and Classification
description:
Practice identifying and classifying different types of matrices. Understand the basic concepts and terminology used in matrix algebra.

**Instructions:**
1. Identify the dimensions (rows × columns) of each matrix
2. Classify each matrix by type (square, rectangular, row, column, etc.)
3. Determine if matrices are equal where applicable
4. Identify special matrix types (diagonal, identity, zero, etc.)

**Matrix A:**
```
[ 1  2  3 ]
[ 4  5  6 ]
```

**Matrix B:**
```
[ 1  0  0 ]
[ 0  1  0 ]
[ 0  0  1 ]
```

**Matrix C:**
```
[ 2  0  0 ]
[ 0  2  0 ]
[ 0  0  2 ]
```

**Matrix D:**
```
[ 0  0  0 ]
[ 0  0  0 ]
```

**Matrix E:**
```
[ 5 ]
[ 3 ]
[ 1 ]
```

**Matrix F:**
```
[ 7  8  9 ]
```

For each matrix, provide:
- Dimensions
- Classification (square/rectangular/row/column matrix)
- Special type (if any)

Compare matrices A and B for equality.
hints: Matrix dimensions are written as rows × columns
A square matrix has equal number of rows and columns
A row matrix has only one row, a column matrix has only one column
Two matrices are equal if they have the same dimensions and identical corresponding elements
Identity matrix has 1s on the main diagonal and 0s elsewhere
Zero matrix contains all zero elements
solution:
**Matrix A:**
- Dimensions: 2 × 3 (rectangular matrix)
- Classification: Rectangular matrix
- Special type: None

**Matrix B:**
- Dimensions: 3 × 3 (square matrix)
- Classification: Square matrix
- Special type: Identity matrix (I₃)

**Matrix C:**
- Dimensions: 3 × 3 (square matrix)
- Classification: Square matrix
- Special type: Scalar matrix (diagonal matrix with equal diagonal elements)

**Matrix D:**
- Dimensions: 2 × 3 (rectangular matrix)
- Classification: Rectangular matrix
- Special type: Zero matrix (all elements are zero)

**Matrix E:**
- Dimensions: 3 × 1 (column matrix)
- Classification: Column matrix
- Special type: None

**Matrix F:**
- Dimensions: 1 × 3 (row matrix)
- Classification: Row matrix
- Special type: None

**Equality Comparison:**
Matrices A and B are NOT equal because they have different dimensions (2×3 vs 3×3).
